PARRY SOUND -Parry Sound 33 isn't out of mind.

As summer starts unofficially this weekend, we revisit it and look forward to Summer 2019.

Parry Sound 33 was reported to the province's forest firefighters at 5:15 p.m. on Wednesday, July 18, 2018 when it was 53.8 hectares on Henvey Inlet First Nation, about 100 km north of Parry Sound. The next day it was 100 hectares in size. By the time Parry Sound 33 was considered under control, and then out on Oct. 31, 11,362 hectares were burnt leaving behind memories of Key River, French River and Henvey Inlet residents' evacuations and lost homes, plus lost tourism business for those on its border.

During Parry Sound 33, Britt was the command centre for firefighters and its department's members helped in the evacuations.

"With our emergency preparedness plan, it was a good working exercise. There were things we might have changed but we had a chance to exercise it and for all intents and purposes it went really well," said Britt fire chief Larry Olds.

The department is working to revamp the plan, based on lessons learned, to layout clear steps ahead of declaring a state of emergency. A state of emergency wasn't declared in Britt.

Parry Sound 33 has changed how some are approaching burning.

"People still have (the fire) on the back of their minds," said Olds. "I'm getting more phone calls this year: 'can we burn or should we burn?' They're more conscience now of burning than they were before...especially when they realize the cost of burning, if it gets out of hand that they could be on the hook for."

The fire had Bear Claw Tours business down 45 per cent from 2017 with people thinking it was in Parry Sound, the town. The good news is that so far his May to November season is starting off on the right foot, despite flooding in Muskoka that has his customers concerned trails here may be under water.

"First of all I have to dig myself out of the 45 per cent hole," said owner Andrew Ryeland. "That means paying back (debt), but I'm hopeful that we'll be able to do that. Unless something else happens, we should be fine."

If there is a forest fire in the District of Parry Sound of similar magnitude, he hopes it's named differently. Parry Sound 33 was the 33rd fire in Parry Sound District but it was confused with the Town of Parry Sound, a situation exasperated when a Toronto television show falsely reported Parry Sound was being evacuated.

In Ontario, the forest fire season starts in April.

In April 2018 the Parry Sound area had 90 mm of rain, 38.5 mm in May, 39.3mm in June and 7.3 mm in July. This year, there was 131.1 mm in April and on May 9, the forecast was up to 60 mm of rain.

Environment Canada weather preparedness meteorologist Peter Kimbell said there's no way of knowing if conditions will change and be closer to those of last year.

"I looked at the forecast for the summer, and really there's no signal," said Kimbell. "It could be anything."

Last year there were 1,300 forest fires in Ontario. Prior to that the 10-year average was 757. This year the first forest fire in this district, Parry Sound 1, was April 17.

The Forest Fire Info Map shows Parry Sound 1 was across the railway tracks that had been a line in the sand for those battling Parry Sound 33, and it was human caused.

"The amount and timing of precipitation is obviously the biggest factor that we see," said spokesperson Shayne McCool of the forest fire season. "When we see a long period without significant rain the vegetation has an opportunity to dry out and it can become more susceptible to fires."

Between April 2018 and March 2019 the province spent $212 million on fighting forest fires and brought in help from the U.S. and Mexico. The base budget this year is $69.8 million. Last month that difference had critics claiming the province had slashed funding.

"There have actually been no cuts to the forest fire fighting funding. Each year Ontario provides about $70 million to support the front line efforts of fighting forest fires. That funding is reevaluated by the Ontario government as the season unfolds," said McCool.

To help cut down the number of fires humans cause the public is reminded to never leave a camp fire unattended and ensure it's completely out.

The cause of Parry Sound 33 was given as a disabled vehicle. No charges under the Forest Fires Prevention Act were laid.

Sidebar:

Story behind the story

Last year's massive fire took the community by storm. Could it happen again? With summer 2019 just around the corner our reporter's mind turned what could be ahead of us.

PARRY SOUND - Life been keeping you too busy to keep up with your local news? Here's a quick hit of some of the most-read stories on ParrySound.com over the last seven days, July 21 to 27, to get you back up to speed.

1. UPDATE- EVACUATION EXPANDED Key River community devastated by fire, evacuation - On Sunday July 21 the OPP and MNR were conducting a mandatory evacuation of people from French River to Pickerel River, from Georgian Bay to Highway 69, due to the forest fire which continues to burn.

2. UPDATE: Parry Sound 33 fire expands to more than 6,500 hectares - The Ministry of Natural Resources and Fire's daily update of forest fire Parry Sound 33, which is still not under control and continues to grow.

3. Key River forest fire fight continues with help from peers in Canada, Mexico, U.S. - On Monday, July 23, the 5,000-hectare Key River fire was being held back by firefighters with some help from Mother Nature.

4. Henvey Inlet First Nation now included in mandatory fire evacuation - Shortly before 8 p.m. on Saturday, July 21, the West Parry Sound OPP issued a release saying members of the Henvey Inlet First Nation were now included in a mandatory evacuation, due to a forest fire burning out of control.

5. UPDATE: Rollover on Highway 400 northbound, Parry Sound cleared - A tractor trailer rollover on the afternoon of Thursday, July 26, diverted northbound Highway 400 traffic through Parry Sound.

It is now listed as held or under control.</p><p>"It's great news," said Ministry of Natural Resources spokeswoman Debbie MacLean in Dryden.</p><p>Across the region, the forest fire situation continued to stabilize. The ministry says it is hoping rain will to continue to help fire crews.</p><p>"We have a good handle on the fires that were critical earlier this month," MacLean said. "We're guardedly optimistic that this rain will bring some relief."</p><p>Although the situation is improving, open fires continue to be banned throughout the region.</p><p>Forest industry workers continue to operate in the region with some restrictions, depending on the site and the forest fire hazard.</p><p>The ministry and industry representatives establish a protocol each season that governs the conditions under which cutters, haulers and other industry workers can continue to work without risk.</p><p>Fire officers continue to monitor a blaze at Ogoki Lake in the far north of Nipigon District. Because it is in a remote area, the fire is being allowed to burn.</p><p>To date, 1,054 forest fires have been recorded in the area this season, burning up about 5,000 square kilometres of land.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) - A state of emergency was declared in Timmins as a fire raged through a forest just three kilometres from the heart of the city.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"It was like a big mushroom cloud and it was crowning - jumping from treetop to treetop - so you almost see the flames from town,'' said Ben Legouffe, information officer for the Ministry of Natural Resources in Timmins.</p><p>"I knew right away it as time to get to work.''</p><p>About 400 people - the entire population of two trailer parks along the Mattagami River - were evacuated soon after the fire broke out at 4.30 p.m.</p><p>About 12 homes near Baker Lake, in the fire's path, were also evacuated. One home was destroyed. No injuries had been reported.</p><p>Mayor Vic Power declared a state of emergency due to conditions of the forest fire which hit the townships of Ogden and Mountjoy.</p><p>More evacuations were expected as the fire headed north.</p><p>The evacuees were taken to the McIntyre Community Centre and were expected to stay with friends or find a hotel room for the night.</p><p>"They won't be going back,'' said Legouffe.</p><p>Legouffe said the fire was threatening to destroy the two trailer parks and a heavily built up area containing many homes and cottages.</p><p>Burning along a 200 hectare front, the fire jumped the 120-metre wide Mattagami River and was headed for the city.</p><p>"It's burning right alongside two of our major saw mills, one of them has a $7-million woodpile and if that went up would burn like a blast furnace,'' said Legouffe.</p><p>"It's still a danger because the wind keeps shifting and there's a lot of smoke which makes it hard to get a view of what's going on.</p><p>"The fire has been throwing flames ahead and starting new fires.''</p><p>He said three water bombers had been brought in to help quell the flames and eight crews from local fire departments and Ministry fire crews were working on the ground.</p><p>"Timmins fire crews, they're using about everything they have.''</p><p>It's the first forest fire of the season in the area but Legouffe said the fires don't usually burn so close to the city.</p><p>Highway 101 West was closed soon after the fire broke out.</p><p>Just a year ago, residents along the Mattagami River battled the worst flooding in more than 20 years.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) - Several families were evacuated from a section of the central Alberta foothills as a pair of forest fires raged late Saturday night near the town of Hinton, about 300 kilometres west of Edmonton.</p><p>"Three structures were lost - we don't know whether they were houses or outbuildings,'' said Evert Smith of Alberta's Land and Forest Service Sunday afternoon.</p><p>"No other structures are in immediate danger. (The families) were evacuated as a precaution.''</p><p>They were fleeing a fire covering 500 hectares that burned about 15 kilometres northwest of Hinton. A second fire, about 1,500 hectares in size, blazed about 30 kilometres south of the town.</p><p>Although the fires were being driven by 80-kilometre winds, neither was expected to menace the community of about 10,000. The wind, however, is hampering firefighting efforts, said Smith.</p><p>"At this time, we're limited to ground action due to high winds,'' he said.</p><p>Firefighting crews, backed up by earthmoving equipment, were still being assembled in both areas Sunday. The causes of the fires have not yet been determined, Smith said.</p><p>Although most forest fires occur in the summer, winter fires do occur along the foothills, areas often blown bare and dry by chinook winds gusting over the mountains.</p><p>"Along the eastern slopes, we have records of fires in all 12 months of the year,'' said Smith.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4T07-4570-TX4V-K0NP-00000-00Grass fire burns in Kamloops, B.C.; forest fire near Ladysmith under control2008-07-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:28ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSGrass fire burns in Kamloops, B.C.; forest fire near Ladysmith under controlCP

KAMLOOPS, B.C. _ Fire crews were battling a glass fire in a residential area of Kamloops, B.C., on Sunday while a forest fire caused by campers on Vancouver Island was under control.

Fire officials initially said the Kamloops blaze, which started Sunday afternoon, was eight to 10 hectares in size, but later increased that figure to 25 hectares.

While the field is in a residential area, B.C Forest Service spokeswoman Jeanne Rucker said it doesn't appear to be a threat to nearby homes.

''It's burning basically in a grassy open field,'' said Rucker.

''There are some subdivisions in the area ... and at this point they're just trying to contain it to keep it from doing anything further.''

Rucker said crews on the ground and in the air were battling the blaze, concentrating on getting the fire under control.

Meanwhile, a two-hectare forest fire about four kilometres west of Ladysmith on Vancouver Island was contained.

The B.C. Forest Service said 30 firefighters are working to completely put out the blaze, which officials believe was caused by careless campers.

''We're concerned that we did find a campfire abandoned in the forest,'' said fire information office Donna MacPherson.

''This is a completely preventable fire. It's disappointing that the public _ whoever was using that location _ didn't take the care to put the fire out.''

Janet and Bill Hoskins at the University's Institute of Industrial Mathematical Sciences.  The $ 70,000 project is funded by the Canada-Manitoba Partnership Agreement in Forestry.  The Hoskins expect to have a prototype system completed by June 1992, which will introduce operational fire suppression staff to Forestry Canada's Canadian Forest Fire Behaviour Prediction (FBP) System, a complex computer model that uses weather, forest type and topographic information to predict such elements as how fast a fire spreads, its intensity, size and shape.<br/>    "Recent statistics stress the importance of this initiative," noted federal Forestry Minister Frank Oberle, adding "In 1989, Manitoba experienced a record loss of over three million hectares of forest, and across Canada each year, about 2.5 million hectares of forest are destroyed, incurring fire management costs of almost $ 275 million."  He indicated that the software will be used by fire management agencies not only across Canada, but in other countries such as the United States, New Zealand, Fiji and Greece, who also use Forestry Canada's Fire Behaviour Prediction System.<br/>    The prototype hypertext system will enable users to combine text, graphics and other media, such as videos, to give users greater flexibility than earlier data base systems.  "Hypertext is curiosity driven", explains Dr. Janet Hoskins.  "Information is cross-linked or layered so that users can access related material in a non-sequential manner.  For example, a user can shift instantly from technical data to picture or mathematical formulas or definitions, following a line of thought through to completion."<br/>    Kelvin Hirsch, a Fire Research Officer with Forestry Canada, believes the training package is an excellent initiative, since predicting fire behaviour is both a science and an art that requires a great deal of skill and knowledge.<br/>    "Fire behaviour prediction is heavily dependent upon an individual's experience and understanding of the basic principles of fire behaviour", says Hirsch.  "Since no model or system can ever account for all the variables that could affect a fire's behaviour, the fire manager must still rely on his or her own ability to cope with unique and unusual situations.  The best possible fire behaviour predictions are those that are based on the systematically calculated values of the Forest Fire Behaviour Prediction System in combination with the opinions and assessments of experienced fire management personnel."<br/>    A complete software package should be available by December 1993.<br/>    /For  further information:  Doug Pronger, (204) 983-7031/</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata (CP) - Campers and cottagers along Gibson Lake were told to leave the area Sunday night as a forest fire raged out of control nearby.</p><p>Lightning sparked a series of fires over the weekend and two blazes near the city continued to concern staff at the Ministry of Natural Resources.</p><p>"We're just going from one lightning fire to another,'' said ministry information officer Ben Legouffe.</p><p>"Our crews are all over the place trying to contain them. It's a bit like juggling.''</p><p>The fires near Timmins were burning over 300 hectares and were impossible to control, Legouffe said. But ministry officials were hopeful the fires would die down overnight.</p><p>"Usually fire won't move much at night when there's no wind, the humidity goes up and the temperature goes down,'' Legouffe said.</p><p>Eight new fires had flared in the eastern region between Sudbury and Cochrane by Sunday afternoon and two fires continued to keep firefighters busy in the northwest around Nipigon.</p><p>"We had 33 new fires (Saturday), the majority lightning-caused,'' said Ken Gibbons, a ministry spokesman in Sudbury. "The bush conditions are very, very dry.''</p><p>The fires were held in check by firefighters but warm winds threatened to spread the flames, Gibbons said.</p><p>A ban on all open fires imposed on the northeast remains in effect until at least Tuesday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier All I could say was, 'Not again. Please, not again.'"</p><p>That devastating call came from Rick Covlin, manager of Air Spray (1967) Ltd., the Edmonton-based aerial forest firefighting company Eric worked for.</p><p>He explained that Eric was co-piloting a large water bomber with Captain Ian MacKay, 42, of B.C. when they struck high ground near Cranbrook, B.C. and were killed instantly.</p><p>Their large, four-engine Lockheed Electra had been dumping a load of fire repellent (a mixture of mud, fertilizer, red dye and a fire-repellent solution) on a forest fire at the time.</p><p>The plane was crushed by the impact and then burst into flames.</p><p>The adventure of the job is exactly what attracted Eric to it, his father said.</p><p>An Elmira District Secondary School graduate, Eric never would have enjoyed a safe, routine job. His father said Eric's love of adventure was shared by his older brother, who worked in and around Whistler as an outback skiing guide and a mountain climbing instructor. He died in January, 1995, when he was swept some 300 metres down a slope.</p><p>KITCHENER-WATERLOO RECORD</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Pilot Eric (CP) - At least one home was in flames and others were being evacuated as a forest fire burned out of control late Wednesday in southwestern Nova Scotia.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Frantic residents scrambled to their cars as firefighters battled flames that had cut a 10-kilometre swath through woods.</p><p>Officials didn't know how many people were evacuated or how far the fire had spread.</p><p>-BODY- Some residents, who at first resisted a voluntary request to leave, were ordered to go later.</p><p>"When the fire's . . . in the backyard, it's a safety concern,'' said RCMP Sgt. Mike Leighton. "We're certainly concerned about their safety right now.</p><p>"We're going to discuss whether certain people will have to be moved.''</p><p>By mid-evening, the fire had jumped Highway 3 and was burning toward the Atlantic coast. The flames were being driven by winds gusting to 70 kilometre an hour.</p><p>As the fire surrounded a number of homes, an elderly man guided firefighters to a grey bungalow as they were attempting to spray down another home's backyard.</p><p>"It's up here, up here, it's where you want to be,'' he yelled as flames came down to the highway, encroaching on the Shag Harbour fire hall.</p><p>Huge billows of smoke could be seen 40 kilometres away and flames shot up over treetops.</p><p>"I could see the fire 30 feet above the trees,'' said Scott McIntosh, who watched from his home across the harbour.</p><p>RCMP were making arrangements to take buses into the area for people who didn't have transportation. Evacuations were also being made as a precautionary measure in nearby Welshtown.</p><p>Authorities reported at least 500 residents in the Shag Harbour and Woods Harbour areas were without power. (Halifax Chronicle-Herald)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Forest fire battled in Havelock-Belmont-

Methuen Township

A 2.7-hectare forest fire in northeastern Peterborough County was under control Monday, according to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

The forest fire near Methuen Lake in Havelock-Belmont-Methuen Township started around 3:47 p.m. Sunday as the result of a lightning strike, according to the ministry.

A 20-hectare forest fire just west of Balsam Lake in the City of Kawartha Lakes that started around 8:07 p.m. Saturday was also under control Monday, according to the ministry.

Meanwhile a 225-hectare forest fire that spread near Dalrymple and Bolsover, about 90 kilometres northwest of Peterborough, caused by a lightning strike late last week was still burning Monday morning.

Ramara Township Fire Rescue Chief Dave McCarthy said crews are monitoring the scene closely.

The City of Kawartha Lakes and Haliburton County both issued full burning bans on Monday.

On Thursday, the ministry was able to get a handle on a 14.3-hectare blaze north of Buckhorn in Trent Lakes township in northwestern Peterborough County.

Man stabbed at Stewart St. home, stepson charged

City police have charged a man after his stepfather was stabbed at a home on Stewart St.

Police were called to the home Friday at 12:20 a.m. The stepfather was taken to hospital and was treated before leaving.

A suspect was found at the home. He was arrested and charged with aggravated assault, assault with a weapon and failing to comply with a probation order.

He appeared in court Friday and was held in custody for a court appearance Tuesday.

His name was not released to protect the identity of the family member involved.

City police did not name the accused man to protect the identity of the stepfather.

Missing girl found safe

City police say a 10-year-old girl reported missing on the weekend has been located and is safe and sound.

Police alerted the public Saturday to keep an eye out for Kiah Eby on Saturday. She had last been seen at 7:30 p.m. Saturday on Ferndale Ave., off Kawartha Heights Blvd. in the west end.

City police thanked the public for assisting in the search.

Ribfest brings back the sizzle this weekend

Ribfest returns to downtown Peterborough Friday and runs to Sunday at Millennium Park.

"It's time to get your bibs ready for some delicious food at Rotary Ribfest this weekend," states Terry Guiel, DBIA executive director, in a release.

Admission is free. Ribfest runs Friday and Saturday from 11 a.m to 10:30 p.m. and Sunday from noon to 5 p.m.

urn:contentItem:5CR5-35P1-DY9S-T458-00000-00Residents in Alberta village evacuated due to forest fire allowed back home2014-07-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:28ZLexisNexisResidents in Alberta village evacuated due to forest fire allowed back homeResidents allowed back home, but on alertThe Canadian Press

VALLEYVIEW, Alta. - Residents of remote community in northwest Alberta have been allowed to return to their homes nearly a week after they left because of a nearby forest fire.

The Municipal District of Greenview says the 10 or so residents could go back as of 6 p.m. Monday, but told them they must be ready to leave on two-hour notice.

The district says it will be contacting residents to tell them they can return home, and arrange transportation if necessary.

A state of local emergency remains in effect and Two Lakes Road remains closed.

The district says the evacuation zone is the same as it was on July 15, when the district ordered the residents to leave, except for the settlement of Nose Creek.

It says there are currently five active fires within the municipality and all but the Red Deer Creek fire is classified as being held.

On the Alberta side of the boundary with British Columbia, the Red Deer Creek fire is being held at the Narraway River, but is considered out of control in B.C.

The total size of the fire is estimated at 348 square kilometres, and the Alberta part is about 30 square kilometres.

Alberta Health Services has issued an air quality advisory for the north zone, including Greenview, due to smoke from the fires.

"I could see the tops of the trees burning."</p><p>Kevin Celloway noticed black smoke behind his home at about 2:30 p.m., but thought someone was burning brush on their property.</p><p>"The RCMP knocked on my door and told me I had to leave. Everything is still in the house. Everything."</p><p>Some residents were allowed to return to their homes by nightfall, but O'Brien said the evacuation order would hold for most homes throughout the night.</p><p>Officials were setting up accommodations in a school for anyone unable to stay with friends or relatives.</p><p>"It's going to be uneasy night for everybody," said RCMP Const. One resident who had been asked to leave his home said flames were shooting up to 10 metres in the air.</p><p>"I haven't seen a fire of this magnitude in my 15 years," said Bruce Burrell, fire safety manager with the Halifax fire service.</p><p>The cause of the blaze wasn't known, although the weather has been warm and dry for almost two weeks.</p><p>More than 100 RCMP and police officers manned barricades, directing traffic or helping in the evacuation effort.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>CP; RCMP officers turn back residents after a forest fire forced the evacuation of several hundred homes in Halifax yesterday. urn:contentItem:5P43-CN31-JDH3-G440-00000-00RE: Hype doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t help forest fire efforts2017-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:28ZLexisNexisLETTERSRE: Hype doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t help forest fire efforts

I am concerned about the tone and misinformation that Tom Fletcher presented in his July 17 column.

It is ludicrous to suggest that those in support of increasing BC's carbon tax think it will put out forest fires. The purpose of a steadily rising price on carbon pollution is to make carbon-intensive goods more expensive than alternatives and to spur innovation.

Carbon taxes don't need to grow government coffers - for example, with carbon fee and dividend the revenue is returned to households as a dividend to help offset the rising costs.

Addressing climate change is a long-term project - one that will likely continue for all our lives. Increasing BC's carbon tax is one way to do our fair share to rapidly reduce carbon pollution worldwide so that hopefully we can avoid the most devastating impacts of climate change.

As our climate warms, the risk of devastating forest fires keeps increasing because higher temperatures and prolonged summer droughts dry out our forests. Governments are working hard to find measures to prevent and manage these long and intense fire seasons. Besides increased forest fires, climate change brings more extreme weather events causing more floods and landslides - like we had across the province this spring.

Sadly, climate change is real and happening now. The well reputed National Oceanic and Atmospheric Agency (NOAA) just announced that this year's global temperature for January to June was the second warmest on record, surprising many scientists because this is not an El Niño year, like last year, when global temperatures tend to be higher.

The current fire situation is of grave concern to many of us here in British Columbia.

It will continue to get worse as years go by if we keep polarizing the issue instead of addressing its root cause - our carbon pollution.

My heart goes out to the thousands of fellow British Columbians impacted by these fires and to the fire fighters who work tirelessly to save our homes.

Laura Sacks

Castlegar, BC

(CP) - City officials have lifted the state of emergency declared last week after a forest fire jumped a river and burned dangerously close to Timmins.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The fire was "declared under control this morning,'' said Ben Legouffe, spokesman for Ontario's Natural Resources Ministry. "It looks pretty good.''</p><p>The fire, which hit its peak Thursday, forced the temporary evacuation of 400 residents - most of them from trailer parks on the outskirts of the city.</p><p>Meanwhile, burning permits within the city's limits have been revoked by fire Chief Lester Cudmore.</p><p>With more warm weather in the forecast, conditions across Northern Ontario remain hazardous with provincial officials saying the risk of more fires is extreme.</p><p>"It's good for holidaying but not for forest fires,'' said Legouffe. "The (fire) hazard will creep up during the week.''</p><p>Meanwhile, firefighters in northwestern Ontario - more than 900 kilometres away - have slowed the advance of a forest fire near Kenora.</p><p>The Natural Resources Ministry has warned people not to light campfires or burn garbage in the area.</p><p>Seventeen firefighters were needed to halt a 96-hectare fire that broke out Saturday northwest of the city, said Mitch Miller, a fire information officer.</p><p>No homes were lost and the few residents evacuated briefly Saturday were allowed to return home that evening.</p><p>"We've had between six and nine fires each day for the past week,'' Miller said Sunday. "Daytime heating continues to be a worry and the threat of thunder showers is building.''</p><p>Lightning strikes are expected to start more fires.</p><p>"If a lightning storm comes through, we could see a hundred fires in a day.''</p><p>There were 23 new fires reported in the province from Friday to Sunday, most of them in nortwestern Ontario.</p><p>Firefighters were working to control 15 fires covering 600 hectares, the Provincial Fire Centre reported today. Four waterbombers - two from Quebec and two from the Northwest Territories - were called in to help.</p><p>"An increase in lightning-caused fires is expected,'' the centre said in a Hopefully we can get in there and get a good handle on it."</p><p>Although she was optimistic the evacuation would only be temporary it was decided later in the evening they would not be allowed back.</p><p>They had the choice of staying at the base camp with firefighters or finding friends or family to bunk with.</p><p>Forest fire officials are diverting resources from the other end of the 150-square-kilometre fire to protect the community, Mcmanus said.</p><p>About 250 firefighters are fighting the blaze, which is burning along both banks of the Athabasca River, about 150 kilometres north of Edmonton.</p><p>Residents of Chisholm were rousted from their beds Friday night when the fire crept with 400 metres of the community.</p><p>The fire, which is burning south of the hamlet, has destroyed several outbuildings and vehicles, but so far no homes have been lost to flames.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5SXJ-KXV1-JDH3-G351-00000-00Forest fire in northeastern Ontario threatens stretch of Trans-Canada Highway2018-07-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:28ZLexisNexisNEWSForest fire in northeastern Ontario threatens stretch of Trans-Canada Highway

PARRY SOUND, Ont. - Crews battling massive fires in northwestern Ontario have been diverted to the heart of the province's cottage country, where a smaller blaze that started more than a week ago is inching closer to a stretch of the Trans-Canada Highway, provincial officials said Monday.

The fire, known as Parry Sound 33, was just six kilometres away from a portion of Highway 69 on Monday - a kilometre closer than it was a day before, a spokesperson for the Ministry of Natural Resources said.

Officials have said it was started by a lightning strike on July 18.

The 89-square-kilometre wildfire in northeastern Ontario has drawn crews away from a blaze three times its size along the province's northwest border, more than a thousand kilometres away, said spokesperson Chris Marchand.

"In the northeast, those fires are happening right in the middle of cottage country," said Chris Marchand. "There are a lot of values, a lot of lives right in the midst of a force of nature ... as opposed to up here (in northwestern Ontario), where a good 50 to 70 per cent of the fires we see, we can just allow them to burn freely on the landscape."

As it crept closer to the Trans-Canada Highway on Sunday, spokesperson Shayne McCool said the flames of Parry Sound 33 also crossed a stretch of CN Rail tracks.

"That section of the fire is a top priority," he said, though he noted that the blaze's location near Georgian Bay means it's bolstered by lake-effect winds that make it harder to fight.

Crews from the United States and Mexico have joined Ontario and Canadian firefighters to tackle the flames. McCool said this has been a landmark year for forest fires in Ontario, mostly due to lots of lightning and precious little rain.

"When that occurs and forest fields are as dry as they are, when lightning strikes, it ignites a lot easier than maybe it would when fields are more wet or damp," he said.

There have been 831 wildfires this year so far, compared to an annual average of 511 over the past 10 years.

The ministry said there were 39 active fires in northeastern Ontario on Monday afternoon and more than 100 in the northwest region. Of those, 44 fires were still raging out of control.

A firefighter from Alberta died on Thursday while fighting a fire near the town of Red Lake, Ont., about 100 kilometres east of the Manitoba boundary. He was identified as Jerry Gadwa, a resident of Kehewin Cree Nation.

urn:contentItem:5SMH-CC41-DY9S-T341-00000-00Members of Manitoba First Nation to return home after forest fire2018-06-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:28ZLexisNexisNATIONALMembers of Manitoba First Nation to return home after forest fireResidents to return to Manitoba First NationThe Canadian Press

WINNIPEG - People who fled a First Nation in east-central Manitoba that was threatened by a massive wildfire are to start returning to their homes this weekend.

The fly-in community of Little Grand Rapids northeast of Winnipeg was evacuated on May 20.

The fire forced hundreds of people to huddle in a school gymnasium as they waited for the smoke to clear enough for planes to land.

Initial reports said 11 houses were destroyed.

A total of 974 residents were forced to leave and have been living in hotels in Winnipeg.

Once the fire threat passed, officials had to deal with restoring power, making sure the water was safe to drink and replacing refrigerators.

The Canadian Red Cross said a small group of residents went up earlier this week to make sure everything was OK.

"The decision on when to return home was made by chief and counsel in consultation with the federal government," they said in a news release.

Starting on Saturday, residents will be flown in to Little Grand Rapids airport and from there transported home by community boat.

Their return will be spread out over three days, with the young and frail to be the last to return to the community so everything will be in place for their arrival.

A spokeswoman with the Red Cross said residents from Paunigassi First Nations, which was also evacuated during the same fire, have not yet been approved by its chief and counsel for a return to the community.

Manitoba Sustainable Development has said the wildfire was caused by a person.

urn:contentItem:51M5-C3X1-JCBF-537K-00000-00Forest fire in Israel kills 40 guards riding bus2010-12-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:28ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A8Forest fire in Israel kills 40 guards riding busSheera FrenkelMcClatchy-TribuneJERUSALEM

At least 40 people were killed Thursday when a massive forest fire spread from Israel's northern city of Haifa into the surrounding hills and incinerated a bus that was carrying prison guards. It was the deadliest fire in Israel's history, according to rescue workers, who struggled to contain flames that raged late into the night.

Most of those killed were guards, who were racing across the north to help evacuate a low-security jail that held Palestinian prisoners.

The bus was travelling along a mountain road when flames suddenly surrounded it, rescue workers said.

The bus driver was unable to avoid the blaze, which was spreading at a rate of more than 160 km/h, firefighters said. When the bus swerved off the road, it was caught in an inferno. All the prison guards were killed immediately, Israeli medics said.

"Anyone who's ever seen a firestorm will know. They could not survive it. They had no protection; they just fell to the road and burned alive," firefighter Dudu Vanunu said.

A police chief and several officers who were driving next to the bus were wounded. They were hospitalized and listed in critical condition Thursday evening, medics said.

The prison, which held about 500 Palestinians, later was evacuated safely.

"This is a disaster of unprecedented proportions," said Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who went to northern Israel on Thursday night to visit colleagues of the dead guards.

Israel celebrated the second night of Hanukkah on Thursday, a holiday known as the "festival of lights" for a legendary miracle in which one can of olive oil was used to light the rededication of the Second Temple in Jerusalem for eight days.

Netanyahu declared a state of national emergency and dispatched every firefighting team in the country to fight the blaze.

At least 2,000 acres had burned through Thursday night.

Israel is suffering through one of the worst droughts in 60 years.

urn:contentItem:5VVC-GTR1-F103-34YX-00000-00Vancouver Island's fog zone fades into the horizon2019-04-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:28ZLexisNexisNEWSVancouver Island's fog zone fades into the horizon

Vancouver Island's "fog zone" is no more.

"When putting on open fire prohibitions, the Coastal Fire Centre has commonly excluded a two-kilometre strip of land along the extreme outer coast of Vancouver Island from Port Renfrew to Port Hardy," said Alan Berry, senior wildfire officer, via press release.

"This area has become known as the 'fog zone' and persons recreating within this zone were allowed to have campfires and local residents could conduct Category 2 open burns. This decision to exclude this area was made because of the lower risk of a wildfire spreading due to the presence of fog and a general lack of community bylaws and campfire procedures in provincial and federal parks in the fog zone."

Following the 2018 forest fire season, a review of the effectiveness of this procedure was conducted with federal and provincial park staff and local governments in the area including other partners such as First Nations.

"The review concluded that many of the reasons the fog zone was implemented had been resolved," noted Berry. "The communities of Bamfield, Ucluelet and Tofino all have open burning bylaws to manager their own local situation and the Pacific Rim National Park has built a system of designed camping sites in its remote areas and campfires are managed through an effective permit system."

As a result, the Coastal Fire Centre has decided that for the 2019 forest fire season it will discontinue use of the Fog Zone concept."

"The Wildfire Act and Wildfire Regulation will administer open burning and prohibited activity restrictions on crown lands including provincial parks while areas covered by local government bylaws and federal parks with their own open burning rules will govern themselves," Berry said.

"The Coastal Fire Centre will work with our partners including BC Parks to ensure a smooth transition into the new process. This change in administration will be implemented when the forest fire danger rating reaches levels where open burning activities become a risk of causing forest fires."

(CP) - A forest fire just north of this northern oil city threatened the region's power supply as it burned out of control Thursday.</p><p>"The forest fires in the Fort McMurray area are threatening two of our large transmission lines that feed the area,'' said Elaine Sagan of ATCO Electric.</p><p>-BODY- "However, at this time both are still in service,'' she said Thursday afternoon.</p><p>There were a number of fires burning near Fort McMurray Thursday, three out of control. None were threatening the town.</p><p>Earlier, one of the blazes just north of town went through an area where ATCO has three smaller transmission lines and damaged one of them, knocking it out of service, Sagan said. The other two lines were still in operation.</p><p>The damage caused surges and fluctuations in the city's power supply, she said. Utility workers were waiting for the all-clear signal from firefighting officials to go in and repair the line.</p><p>Two of the fires - each less than one square kilometre in size - were about five kilometres north of Fort McMurray along Highway 63, which leads to the Suncor and Syncrude oilsands plants.</p><p>The third, which is about 10 square kilometres in size, is about 25 kilometres north of town in a remote area.</p><p>Rick Arthur of Alberta's Land and Forest Service said firefighters were diverted away from the larger fire to tackle the blazes near town.</p><p>But he added they were reassessing their priorities because the large fire was growing rapidly.</p><p>"It is spreading. We are losing ground on it,'' Arthur said.</p><p>Officials said the blazes did not threaten the community but the smoke was the hazard. On Wednesday the highway to the oilsands plants was partially closed because the smoke caused poor visibility.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:51WF-6D71-JCBG-9126-00000-00Angry crowd forces Israeli premier to halt speech at ceremony for 42 killed in forest fire2011-01-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:28ZLexisNexisFOREIGN GENERAL NEWSAngry crowd forces Israeli premier to halt speech at ceremony for 42 killed in forest fireAP

JERUSALEM _ Angry relatives of 42 Israelis killed in a huge forest fire last month forced Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to stop his speech Wednesday at a ceremony honouring the dead.

Family members shouted that he should be held responsible for the handling of the disaster response. Others directed their anger at Interior Minister Eli Yishai, who was escorted out of the hall. Firefighting services are part of his ministry.

Israel's firefighting services were unprepared for the huge fire, which destroyed swaths of forest in Israel's north. Since Israel lacked any suitable aircraft, Netanyahu had to appeal for help from abroad. Several nations, including the United States, sent firefighting planes that helped douse the blaze after four days.

During Wednesday's disturbance, bodyguards rushed toward the podium and formed a line to keep people away from Netanyahu.

Relatives yelled at him to resign and called the ceremony a disgrace. They objected to his attempt to identify with their personal pain without taking responsibility for the tragedy.

''We will find out the truth. We will not rest until we find out the truth,'' shouted one man from the crowd.

Netanyahu had to stop talking for several minutes while security officers restored order.

Among those who heckled Netanyahu was Danny Rosen, the partner of Israel's highest-ranking female police officer, Ahuva Tomer, the police chief of the northern city of Haifa. She was killed when flames enveloped a bus she was accompanying. It was carrying prison service workers toward a jail, where they were sent to evacuate prisoners.

The flames reached the outskirts of Haifa, Israel's third-largest city.

Netanyahu has attended a number of functions and meetings of officials in the aftermath of the fire, by far the largest forest fire in Israel's history.

B.C</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">KELOWNA, B.C -- Residents of more than 160 homes in a tiny southern B.C. town were forced to flee Wednesday when a Arm.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Canadian Press</p></bodyText></section><p>Firefighters were hampered by steep, rugged terrain.</p><p>By mid afternoon, the blaze had jumped the up in flames, said forest service spokeswoman Mitzi Bushell.</p><p>The situation was "out of control at this point," she said.</p><p>Reached minutes before fleeing her home and business, Chris Norris, co-owner of Silver Creek General Store, described the sudden turn of events as heartbreaking.</p><p>The Norrises kept their store open as long as possible so evacuees could get last-minute supplies, she said.</p><p>All available equipment was being used to fight the fire, said Jennifer Crawford, a fire information officer in Kamloops.</p><p>A lightning strike ignited the fire July 28, but it stayed quiet until late Monday when winds began to fan the flames.</p><p>More than 170 fires have erupted in the last six days as record temperatures have left area forests bone dry.</p><p>Evacuees were being sent to the Salmon Arm community centre, said forest service spokeswoman Sylvia Pang.</p><p>Forest Service spokeswoman Wendy Stewart said a 40-unit trailer park near the 150-hectare urn:contentItem:5PDW-TWV1-DY9S-T46B-00000-00'Running for our lives': Manitoba First Nations chief describes fire evacuation2017-09-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:28ZLexisNexisNATIONAL'Running for our lives': Manitoba First Nations chief describes fire evacuationOne shelter closing for forest fire evacueesSteve LambertThe Canadian Press

WINNIPEG - The leader of a northern Manitoba First Nation says an evacuation to escape a forest fire was a harrowing experience made harder by the lack of proper infrastructure and a quick way out.

"Before we knew it, we had this huge fire column that was hanging over the entire community," Wasagamack Chief Alex McDougall said of the evening last week when the fire that had been in the distance suddenly swept toward the reserve.

"We had our moms with their kids on their arms, with whatever they could grab, whatever clothes they had on their back - the fire behind them - and we were literally running for our lives."

Wasagamack was one of three communities evacuated last week because of a large fire that came within one kilometre of some homes and sent thick smoke in the air.

Wasagamack faced a bigger challenge than St. Theresa Point and Garden Hill because it has no airstrip. Its 2,000 residents had to take turns squeezing into small boats and make the 20-minute journey across Island Lake to St. Theresa Point. The effort continued well into the night.

"We were covered in pine needles, embers. And it just turned dark," McDougall said. Small lights were used on the boats to guide the evacuees safely across the water.

Over the next 36 hours or so, many of the evacuees would go on from St. Theresa Point to Garden Hill, where military transport planes can land. From there they were taken to hotel rooms or large emergency shelters more than 500 kilometres south in Winnipeg and Brandon.

One woman had a miscarriage during the trek, McDougall said, and another died of diabetes-related complications after she fled south. Two evacuees in Brandon were hospitalized with pneumonia related to smoke inhalation.

McDougall and other Indigenous leaders called a news conference Wednesday to demand an airport for Wasagamack - something they said governments promised more than 50 years ago.

"They deserve infrastructure that keep their people safe," said Sheila North Wilson, grand chief of Manitoba Keewatinowi Okimakanak, which represents First Nations communities across northern Manitoba.

"In this day and age, it's not acceptable for them to have to leave ... the way they did."

More than 5,000 people in total were forced to flee Wasagamack, Garden Hill and St. Theresa Point. More than 1,000 were put up in two large emergency shelters - one in the Winnipeg Convention Centre and another at an indoor soccer complex.

The Canadian Red Cross, which is managing the evacuations for the federal government, said Wednesday it no longer needed the convention centre because more hotel rooms in the city have become available with the end of the summer tourist season.

Some evacuees also found lodging with friends or relatives.

"Less than 375 evacuees stayed at the two shelters (Tuesday) night, with less than 125 at the convention centre," the agency said in a written statement.

"The remaining evacuees will either move to the soccer complex shelter or to hotel rooms that become available."

Meanwhile, health officials said one confirmed case of mumps has surfaced in an evacuee in a shelter in Brandon.

Dr. Richard Rusk, provincial medical officer of health for communicable diseases, said there are four more suspected cases among evacuees in Winnipeg.

Evacuees showing symptoms are being moved to local hotels to help stop the illness from spreading.

A different fire near the Poplar River First Nation improved this week, which has allowed about 750 people to start returning to their homes. That has also opened up hotel space.

(CP) - Firefighter Martin Pell calls himself "one mad soldier'' fighting a vicious battle against nature.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"When it gets this bad, Mother Nature calls the shots and she's firing a helluva lot more bullets than we can take,'' said Pell, glaring angrily at billows of white smoke from a Twin Otter flying about 1,200 metres over burning northwestern Ontario forestland.</p><p>The back of his orange coveralls bear the words Fire Control. But Pell, 49, admits the 1,000 firefighters who have advanced into northwestern Ontario can only wish they had control over the area's more than 220 fires.</p><p>Fires have claimed 1,300 square kilometres of forestland. Many call them the worst fires to scar the region in 15 years.</p><p>The war is being fought with 10 water bombers, eight fixed-wing aircraft and more than 60 helicopters.</p><p>They're getting orders from a military-style command post - the fire response centre in Dryden, Ont., about 200 kilometres south of Red Lake.</p><p>"It's like a war game,'' said Rob Rutherford, the 40-year-old command officer who's spending 16-hour days at the centre next to the town's airport.</p><p>"You're trying to position yourself against the enemy. In our case, it's these fires,'' he said, casting his eyes over wall-sized maps covered with arrows and dots charting the course of fires, water bombers and fire crews engaged in the battle.</p><p>"It's stress with a big S. This just keeps building and building and building,'' added Ed Bons, one of a handful of ministry workers crowding the tiny fire response centre.</p><p>Bons helps decide where each water bomber and fire crew will go. Other fire intelligence officers worked their computer terminals to track weather and burning conditions as well as possible fire hazards, mapping out a plan of attack.</p><p>But the soldiers can't keep ahead of the enemy. Mother Nature has been a relentless foe.</p><p>Temperatures have reached 40C, lightning strikes nightly and there's no rain in sight. It's been that way for three weeks and forecasts predict little change, said Debbie MacLean, a spokeswoman for Ontario's Ministry of Natural Resources.</p><p>While no one has died, the blazes have forced about 1,500 natives to become refugees. Six settlements have been forced to flee to safety.</p><p>Exhausted firefighters are wilting under the heat of battle.</p><p>As Pell soars over the skies on his way from Dryden to Red Lake to fight a blaze, he said he's determined his side will triumph soon.</p><p>"We aren't giving up, no way. We're gonna win this war.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier MARIE</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>SAULT STE. MARIE - The 1995 forest fire season in Ontario cost the natural resources ministry more than $101 million, making it one of the most costly ever.</p><p>Bob Thomas of the ministry's Aviation and Fire Management Centre, based in Sault Ste. Marie, says 2,118 fires burned over 620,000 hectares of forest and forced close to 3,500 people to flee their homes and communities.</p><p>The forest fire season runs from April 1 to Oct. 30.</p><p>Thomas says it's difficult to compare fires on a year-to-year basis because of the many factors involved. For example, there were more fires - 2,560 in 1991, with only 318,000 hectares of forest burned. That's almost one-half this year's tally.</p><p>The most serious fires were near the lumbering community of Dubreuilville, 280 kilometres north of Sault Ste. Marie. The 1,200 residents of the community were forced to flee to nearby Wawa, White River and Sault Ste. Marie as the flames approached to within a few kilometres of the town.</p><p>The residents were evacuated Aug. 21 and returned a week later after firefighters beat back the flames and saved the town.</p><p>It was a dramatic fire season, says Thomas.</p><p>"In the twenties, forest fires destroyed over 800,000 hectares of forest, but they were not able to map the burned-out areas like we can today so it's difficult to compare."</p><p>In 1994 there were just over 1,000 forest fires, destroying 83,000 hectares and costing the province $12 million.</p><p>Two thousand firefighters from other parts of Canada and the United States were brought in to help the 750 firefighters hired for the summer by the ministry.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata (CP) - Larry and Corine Munn have probably never made the drive from Fredericton to their home in Taymouth as fast as they did on Sunday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Their house was one of several that came within 90 metres of a fire raging through woods about 25 kilometres north of the provincial capital.</p><p>-BODY- The homes escaped harm but several power line poles burned, leaving about 3,500 households without power.</p><p>NB Power said electricity might not be restored until Monday morning.</p><p>Corine Munn said her family rushed home after a friend called to warn them about the fire, which consumed about 10 hectares.</p><p>She said neighbours helped them empty the house in case it was engulfed.</p><p>"We got everything out,'' Corine said, noting her children were especially worried about their two dogs. "My daughter went right panicky.''</p><p>Three water bombers fought the fire through the afternoon, taming it by early evening, said Art Cronin, a duty officer with the province's forest fire centre.</p><p>"The winds were in our favour and they slowed down just when we needed them to,'' he said.</p><p>More than 100 firefighters, drawn from the province's Natural Resources Department and three area fire departments, fought the blaze, said Cronin.</p><p>The Taymouth fire was just one of four fires the province was called on to help fight.</p><p>Cronin said a forest fire in the Salisbury area consumed about 18 hectares, while one in Barryville spread across 10 hectares. A two-hectare forest fire in Big Cove threatened homes, but no structures were lost, he said. (Fredericton Gleaner)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier "All that stuff from last fall gets dried out from the wind and it burns well, so oddly enough this time of year the forest fire index can be pretty high.''</p><p>A department helicopter being used for a media tour of the new Highway 104 in Nova Scotia, which opens today, was put on standby for fire duty.</p><p>In New Brunswick, the index is already on the lower end of extreme.</p><p>There have been 133 fires reported in Nova Scotia since March, covering more than 275 hectares. Over the same period last year, Natural Resources reported 203 fires covering 603 hectares.</p><p>"People should be careful because it is the time of the year where there is a little more danger of forest fires breaking out,'' said Henshaw.</p><p>"One of the big factors is the wind is fairly strong these days and that dries things out quickly.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier teachers</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>VANCOUVER, Sept. 2</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Like all British Columbians, teachers have <br/>been horrified to see the catastrophic forest fires raging throughout our <br/>province this summer, threatening so many homes and communities. <br/>    "Teachers want to do all we can to help our colleagues, students and <br/>their families during this terrible time," said BCTF President Neil Worboys. <br/>"Through our Federation, we are launching a Forest Fire Relief Fund for both <br/>students and teachers affected by the fires." <br/>    The BCTF is kicking off the fund with an initial contribution of <br/>$125,000. <br/>    "To help that sum grow, we're encouraging local teacher associations, <br/>individual members and retired teachers also to contribute," Worboys said. <br/>"We've already heard about many creative fund-raising efforts teachers are <br/>launching in their communities, and I have no doubt other activities will be <br/>planned once everyone's back to school." <br/>    The fund will be used to offer a gift of $200 for each student affected <br/>by the forest fires to help purchase school supplies and the many other <br/>necessities at this time of year. <br/>    "Students and their families face extremely high expenses this month, <br/>especially with the cost of school supplies and course fees going up all the <br/>time," Worboys said. "We'll be setting up support committees in the fire- <br/>stricken communities to help parents of the thousands of affected students to <br/>access the fund." <br/>    The BCTF Forest Fire Relief Fund also provides grants of $5,000 for <br/>teachers who have lost their homes to fire and $1,000 for those who were <br/>evacuated due to a forest fire threat. </p><p> "It's an old saying in the union movement that 'an injury to one is an <br/>injury to all,'" Worboys said. "We're trying to express that support and <br/>solidarity with our colleagues and students who have been hurt by these <br/>disastrous fires." This week Worboys will be travelling to several of the fire- <br/>affected areas to meet with teachers, students, and parents. <br/>    Teachers will also be working with parents and other community members to <br/>help children overcome the trauma of losing their homes or being uprooted <br/>during such a frightening experience. Members of the B.C. School Counsellors' <br/>Association and the BCTF Social Justice Advisory Committee have prepared tips <br/>for parents and teachers to support children as they deal with the impact of <br/>the fires. urn:contentItem:4PB7-7X10-TX4V-K3HM-00000-00Power cut off to four B.C. Interior towns as forest fire approaches2007-08-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:28ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSPower cut off to four B.C. Interior towns as forest fire approachesCP

VANCOUVER (CP) _ Power has been turned off to four towns in the B.C. Interior as a forest fire encroaches.

The communities of Burton, Nakusp, Needles and Fauquier in the West Kootenay were without electricity Wednesday after the Arrow Lake Penstock fire burned through major power lines.

B.C. Hydro spokeswoman Jennifer Walker-Larson says electricity will be cut off to about 2,700 people for at least the next two days.

Officials say the blaze is not a threat to buildings but smoke is heavy in the Needles area.

The B.C. Forest Service says three homes have been evacuated northeast of Slocan, about one kilometre from the Springer Creek forest fire, while 11 other homes remain on evacuation alert.

But fire information officer Gwen Eamer says it's only a precautionary move, and it doesn't mean the flames are on the move.

Eamer says fire officials are also keeping a watch on 16 homes one kilometre from the Arrow Lake Penstock fire but an evacuation alert has not been put in place.

The Highways Ministry is warning motorists travelling on Highways 6 and 23 that they won't be able to get gas because the power is out at local service stations.

The Hamil Creek wildfire near Argenta has placed four homes on evacuation alert.

The biggest blaze in the region is the Sitkum Creek blaze northeast of Nelson, which covers 10 square kilometres but is not threatening any homes.

urn:contentItem:5SWX-RBP1-F105-61GY-00000-00Rain has helped but forest fires in North Bay region continue to burn2018-07-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:28ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Rain has helped but forest fires in North Bay region continue to burn

NORTH BAY - UPDATE (11:09 p.m. Tuesday, July 24): By the evening of Tuesday, July 24, there were 55 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, 17 are not yet under control, 38 are either being held, under control or being observed.

River Valley Fire Cluster

The River Valley Fire Cluster includes two fires: North Bay 62 and North Bay 42. Both fires are now being held. North Bay 25 is being monitored.

There are 138 people working on these fires including firefighters from Ontario, British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Nova Scotia and Mexico.

Fire behavior was relatively quiet Tuesday, July 24, due to the rain, increased cloud cover and higher humidity levels. Fires received about 50 millimetres of precipitation over the past 48 hours.

Temagami Fire Cluster:

There are 45 firefighters, with six helicopters working on fires in the Temagami cluster.

Due to the rain received in the area, fire activity was greatly reduced on all fires within the Temagami cluster. These conditions made for another great working day for firefighters, as they are able to get into hot spot areas safely.

Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster:

The Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster remains at 27,579 hectares, with 253 firefighters and support staff, and 11 helicopters assigned to this cluster. All resources were assigned to North Bay 72 today. The team continues to observe North Bay 59 and has assumed the responsibility for North Bay fires 18, 19, 46, 59 and 61.

Restricted Fire Zone expanded

Due to the extreme fire hazard, several recent periods of heavy lightning, little precipitation and increased forest fire, the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry has expanded the Restricted Fire Zone. This expansion of the current Restricted Fire Zone will be in effect as of 12:01 a.m. on Tuesday, July 24, and remain in place until further notice.

The expanded Restricted Fire Zone now includes Zones 24, 25 and 26 which would include areas south of the French River, including Parry Sound, from Georgian Bay east to the Quebec border, including Algonquin Provincial Park and from Renfrew north to Mattawa.

To date, the current Restricted Fire Zone covers Zones 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 24, 25 and 26 and restrictions will remain in place until further notice. See the fire map for an outline of the zones covered.

During a Restricted Fire Zone, the use of open fires - such as campfires, or burning of brush or debris, is restricted. Failure to comply could result in fines of up to $25,000 and three months in jail, as well as financial responsibility for the costs incurred in fighting a forest fire.

Portable gas or propane stoves are permitted for use for cooking or warmth, though they should be closely monitored. Portable charcoal barbecues and Hibachis are not permitted unless within 100 metres of a dwelling, or within an organized campground.

Commercial campground operators may allow their guests to enjoy campfires during a Restricted Fire Zone period provided they meet certain conditions in the Outdoor Fires Regulation (207/96).

The Restricted Fire Zone is a temporary measure to reduce the number of new human-caused wildfires as the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry expects the elevated forest fire hazard to continue into the foreseeable future.

Ontario is receiving support from across Canada, the United States and Mexico to assist with the fire situation. Additional personnel and equipment are expected to arrive in the province in the coming days, including ignition specialists from Parks Canada.

Travel restrictions

Pursuant to the Emergency Area Order signed July 21, an Implementation Order has been issued by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry prohibiting access and travel in portions of North Bay, Kirkland Lake and Sudbury Districts where there are public safety hazards as a result of increased fire activity.

The Order restricts travel, access and use in an identified area and may be modified regularly to reflect changing fire conditions.

This measure has been put in place to ensure public safety while allowing fire personnel to safely and effectively suppress the fires in the identified area.

All travel and use of the following roads are prohibited: McLaren's Road, Gibbons Road, Baie-Jeanne Road, South Pardo Road, Beauty Lake Road, St. Joseph's Road, George Gordon and Iron Lake Road, Cooke Lake Road, Liskeard Lumber Road, Klock Lake Road, Crane Lake Road, Roadhouse Tower Road, Indian Bay Road, Mountain Lake Road, and Goulard Road starting at Lower Goose Falls.

All modes of travel/access into Lady Evelyn-Smoothwater, Obabika River, Makobe-Grays River, Solace and Sturgeon River Provincial Parks, and all Crown lands is prohibited.

Use of the Red Squirrel Lake Road beyond the Barmac Gate is prohibited.

All use and occupation of Crown land on or within 500 metres of all described closed roads is prohibited.

If a member of the public believes that access within the restricted travel area is necessary for non-recreational purposes, please call North Bay District at 705-475-5546 (8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.) or Kirkland Lake District at 705-568-3240 (8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.) to request a travel authorization permit. For requesting access to Red Squirrel Lake Road, please call North Bay District. MNRF will review the request for access based on the rationale provided, local fire activity, and the potential fire risk.

See the restricted travel and access areas on this PDF map (Note: this map gets updated regularly).

Smoke concerns

Many Ontario residents have reported smoke drift in their communities. Smoky conditions are expected to continue as a number of fires remain active throughout the northeast region until weather patterns and fire activity change.

The Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry is reminding the public that if they do see flames or smoke, please report it, and stay away from the area in the interest of public safety.

If you have questions or concerns about smoke and your health, please contact Tele Health Ontario at 1-866-797-0000.

To report a forest fire located north of the French and Mattawa rivers, please dial 310-FIRE (3473)

To report a forest fire located south of the French or Mattawa rivers, please dial 911.

Follow Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry on Twitter @ONForestFires

For up to date information on current fires in the province or to check the forest fire hazard in your area, visit Ontario.ca/forestfire.

urn:contentItem:5V55-HDX1-F103-3208-00000-00Forest fire in northeastern Ontario threatens stretch of Trans-Canada Highway2018-07-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:28ZLexisNexisNEWSForest fire in northeastern Ontario threatens stretch of Trans-Canada Highway

PARRY SOUND, Ont. — Crews battling massive fires in northwestern Ontario have been diverted to the heart of the province's cottage country, where a smaller blaze that started more than a week ago is inching closer to a stretch of the Trans-Canada Highway, provincial officials said Monday.

The fire, known as Parry Sound 33, was just six kilometres away from a portion of Highway 69 on Monday — a kilometre closer than it was a day before, a spokesman for the Ministry of Natural Resources said.

Officials have said it was started on July 18 and the cause is under investigation.

The 89-square-kilometre wildfire in northeastern Ontario has drawn crews away from a blaze three times its size along the province's northwest border, more than a thousand kilometres away, said spokesman Chris Marchand.

"In the northeast, those fires are happening right in the middle of cottage country," said Chris Marchand. "There are a lot of values, a lot of lives right in the midst of a force of nature … as opposed to up here (in northwestern Ontario), where a good 50 to 70 per cent of the fires we see, we can just allow them to burn freely on the landscape."

As it crept closer to the Trans-Canada Highway on Sunday, spokesman Shayne McCool said the flames of Parry Sound 33 also crossed a stretch of CN Rail tracks.

"That section of the fire is a top priority," he said, though he noted that the blaze's location near the Georgian Bay means it's bolstered by lake effect winds that make it harder to fight.

Crews from the United States and Mexico have joined firefighters from throughout Ontario and the rest of Canada to tackle the flames. McCool said this has been a landmark year for forest fires in Ontario, mostly due to lots of lightning and precious little rain.

"When that occurs and forest fields are as dry as they are, when lightning strikes it ignites a lot easier than maybe it would when fields are more wet or damp," he said.

Officials said nine new fires were confirmed in the northwest region by mid-afternoon Monday.

One was burning four kilometres northwest of the community of North Spirit Lake, while another was located approximately nine kilometres south of WabigoonLake Ojibway Nation.

There have been 888 wildfires this year so far, compared to an annual average of 517 over the past 10 years.

The ministry said there were 39 active fires in northeastern Ontario on Monday afternoon and more than 100 in the northwest region. Of those, 44 fires were still raging out of control.

A firefighter from Alberta died on Thursday while fighting a fire near the town of Red Lake, Ont., about 100 kilometres east of the Manitoba boundary. He was identified as Jerry Gadwa, a resident of Kehewin Cree Nation.

SANDIE RINALDO: In Nova Scotia tonight a huge cheer went up at an emergency shelter as officials announced victory in the battle against a major forest fire and told most of the 5,000 evacuees that their homes had been saved. urn:contentItem:7YH6-HJ81-2R6R-54W0-00000-00People allowed to return home after cooler temperatures help forest fire crews2010-05-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:28ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSPeople allowed to return home after cooler temperatures help forest fire crewsCP

REDWING, Sask. _ Crews battling a forest fire in northern Saskatchewan got some help from Mother Nature in the form of cooler temperatures and higher humidity.

That allowed people who were evacuated earlier this week in Redwing, a hamlet north of Prince Albert, to return home Wednesday.

''We felt it was appropriate to lift the evacuation order,''said Larry Fladager, reeve of the RM of Buckland.

The fire management team met late Wednesday afternoon and, after looking at conditions, decided to allow people to return home. About 60 homes were evacuated due to the blaze, which covered 298 hectares.

Access is being restricted by police officers and only home and small business owners are being allowed into the area as fire operations are ongoing, Fladager said.

''The state of emergency is still in effect given that the fire conditions are in the area and (they) could change ...,'' he said.

''As a result of that we are asking the homeowners in the area to be prepared to move at short notice if conditions did change.''

Colin King, Saskatchewan's deputy fire commissioner, says the blaze started in the garage of the home that burned down.

He can't say how the fire started, but adds there are no indications that it was anything other than an accident.

(Prince Albert Daily Herald)

urn:contentItem:5PB8-HMV1-F105-649F-00000-00Re: Notes from the forest fire zone2017-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:28ZLexisNexisOPINIONRe: Notes from the forest fire zone

Dear Mr. Fletcher,

This is the first time in 64 years of life that I have felt compelled to respond to an editorial. As a resident of 108 Mile Ranch who was evacuated for 15 days, and a professional counsellor who is seeing a sharp increase in clients with stress related disorders and depression, I believe that your article inaccurately misrepresents the devastation of our wildfires.

The tone of your article is that- "it's no big deal; not much damage to see." How disrespectful to the thousands of residents who have been displaced and the hundreds who have lost homes, outbuildings, businesses, livestock, etc., etc.

You said you drove from Highway 24 onto Highway 97 through to Prince George. How did you miss three kilometres of burned forest from Canim Hendrix Road just north of 100 Mile House through to 105 Mile? If you had taken a moment to drive in this area and two to three km off 105 Mile Road West and Tatton Station Road, you would have seen total devastation of forest and many homes! It would have left you numb and heart sick as it did when we drove through.

You say that "the only visible scars...[around] Williams Lake" was "where a brush fire ran up to one of the many widening and paving projects...and the construction area acted as a firebreak and only a small spot burned..." Are you kidding me? Did you not see the miles of burned forest that ran along the highway and into the Sugar Cane Reserve? If you had taken just another moment to drive up the road to Horsefly, you would have seen burned forest, a burned home, and near loss of the 153 Mile log home building plant for Pioneer Log Homes (aka The Timber Kings TV reality show).

And, I'm only referring to my immediate area from 100 Mile to Williams Lake. You should take a drive and see the devastation from Ashcroft through to Clinton on Highway 97. It is sickening.

Also in your editorial, you cite some very inaccurate statistics about the history of wildfires. If you listened to the news reports from Aug. 16, you would have learned that the 2017 wildfire season has already surpassed the 1958 record year, and we are far from being out of the woods with many remaining weeks of hot, dry weather and potential lightning storms. This has been, and will be by far and away, the most destructive wildfire season in B.C. history!

I would like to see you print an apology to the citizens of British Columbia (especially those of us directly affected), as well as correct your statistics.

We are going to need many months and years of financial support to help us rebuild our lives and businesses; unfortunately, an article such as yours makes it look like it's all been media hyperbole and that intelligent people shouldn't be buying into the spin. Shameful and hurtful.

Debbie Hancock

Certified Canadian Counsellor

108 Mile Ranch

urn:contentItem:5NV0-F7M1-F105-62YG-00000-00Raging forest fire kills more than 60 in Portugal2017-06-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:52:28ZLexisNexisCANADA / WORLDPg. A6Raging forest fire kills more than 60 in PortugalMany of the victims died in their vehicles while attempting to fleeHelena Alves and Armando Franca The Associated Press

A raging forest fire in central Portugal sent flames sweeping over roads, killing at least 62 people, many of them trapped in their cars as they tried to flee, officials said Sunday.

The country's prime minister called it "the biggest tragedy" in Portugal in decades and declared three days of national mourning.

"The dimensions of this fire have caused a human tragedy beyond any in our memory," Prime Minister Antonio Costa told reporters on his arrival at the scene Sunday.

"Something extraordinary has taken place and we have to wait for technicians to properly determine its causes."

A huge wall of thick smoke and bright red flames towered over the top of trees in the forested Pedrogao Grande area some 150 kilometres northeast of Lisbon where a lightning strike was believed to have sparked the blaze Saturday.

Investigators found a tree that was hit during a "dry thunderstorm," the head of the national judicial police told Portuguese media.

Dry thunderstorms are frequent when falling water evaporates before reaching the ground because of high temperatures.

More than 350 soldiers on Sunday joined the 700 firefighters who have been struggling to put out the blaze.

Authorities say temperatures as high as 40 C in the area in recent days might have also played a part in the inferno.

Resident Isabel Brandao said she had feared for her life when she saw the blaze.

"Yesterday we saw the fire but thought it was very far. I never thought it would come to this side," she said Sunday. "At 3:30 a.m., my mother-in-law woke me up quickly and we never went to sleep again. We were afraid the fire would reach us."

Other locals were also shocked.

"This is a region that has had fires because of its forests, but we cannot remember a tragedy of these proportions," said Valdemar Alves, the mayor of Pedrogao Grande.

"I am completely stunned by the number of deaths."

State broadcaster RTP showed terrifying images of several people on a road trying to escape the intense smoke that had reduced visibility to a few metres.

A young man shared a bottle of water with a distraught woman as she stumbled down the road.

Interior Ministry official Jorge Gomes said firefighting crews were having difficulties battling the fire, which was "very intense" in at least two of its four fronts.

He said authorities were worried about strong winds that could help spread the blaze further.

Schools in the area were closed until further notice and outdoor fires were banned, authorities announced Sunday.

Gomes gave a grim description of the deaths to RTP. He said at least 30 people died inside their cars as they tried to flee between the towns of Figueiro dos Vinhos and Castanheira de Pera.

He said 17 others died right outside their cars or by the road, 11 people died in the forest and two people died in a car accident related to the fire and information was missing on the other deaths. Gomes said 54 people were also injured.
